instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message:
Having this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. liquid spilled around led connector, <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> area.

no power.
fixed <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> area, and power on,fan spins. but no video.( no chime sound)

check back light circuit,nothing on l8300.

checked CPU vcore and it's there.

connector got replaced with new one already.

any advice?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
[SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message:
sorry for a delayed reply, been busy on other boards.

YES, plug in usb mouse and it does light up

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message: Do a PRAM reset and check for chime.

[SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message: yes it's there , i checked L7310 L7320 L7330 all have voltages

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message: is this no backlight or no display?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message: Using a known good LCD? Tried external video?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message:
yes both , no video at all. not back light issue.
Checked with a DC power supply,compare with good board.  

good board should jump from 0.01 to 1.4 AMP after boot up.
this one only goes to 0.4A then stop, looks like some voltage is not coming out, but checked all big coil , they all exist already. even CPU vcore comes out already.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message: Pretty much out of options here. Check closely for more corrosion again, especially <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, clock, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, SMC. If all ok then could still be dead CPU.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message:
I poled around and compared with the good board, found one thing can be the hint.

diode mode on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, only gets 0.035
the good one is around 0.319

but when powers on, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is 3.3v still , doesn't look like pulling down. something shorted?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message: That is indeed way too low. That is also a rail that has pretty much everything connected to it. Maybe inject 3V there and see if anything warms up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message:
removed <RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR>, diode mode 0 on its pin 1.

damn.turn out to be one of the shits I never wanted to do. it's a dead PCH. 

it's SR17D,having one last piece here, will do the BGA replacement and update back

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid spilled, restored power but no post.
threads.message:
HAHA, it's my lucky day. replaced the PCH, power up and took a while to post. 

knowing it's the ME issue, flashed the bios with cleaned me file. all boots up and works now!!

thanks for the advice guys!
